body:
One more point from me:
- Use of transformers that are applied on the index such as the `DateTimeFeatures` transformer and other transformers that could be applied to the hierarchy features of hierarchical time series.

> * use of contemporary `X`, use of shifted `X` (by forecasting horizon)

Would that force passing `fh` on fit?

> Would that force passing `fh` on fit?

I suppose so? But isn't it needed in `fit` for all the direct strategies, since it goes into the shifts of `y` in all cases?

PR with a prototype design for direct and recursive forecasting:
https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/3333

Solves the above points as follows:

>lagging X and lagging y, lagging y but not lagging X

reducers by default *do not apply any transformations (incl lagging) to `X`*, only to `y`.
* to lag `X`, the `Lag` transformer needs to be applied in a pipeline to exogeneous data.
* to lag `X` and not `y`, apply the `Lag` trafo to exog, and leave the window length parameter at zero.
* lagging `y` an not `X` is the standard behaviour.

 > use of contemporary X, use of shifted X (by forecasting horizon)

In direct reduction, these are options, via parameter `X_treatment` that can be `"concurrent"` or `"shifted"`. In recursive reduction, concurrent is default. Shifted is obtained by lagging `X` with a lag of 1 (we could turn thsi into a parameter, too).

> use of transformers on X, e.g., window summarizer

Transformers for `X` are not passed to the reducers, but need to be applied via a pipeline.
This is more modular, and avoids duplication and "god class" like parameter handling.

> removing missing values created due to shifting/windowing

done by parameter `impute` which is looped through to `Imputer`.
All options in `Imputer` are available in reduction.

`Imputer` has no missing value removal, but that could be added as an option, and would also add the option to the reducers, via the estimator modular dependency.

> treating missing values created due to shifting/windowing (e.g. filling)

option via the `Imputer`.

> treating missing values from shifting/windowing differently from pre-existing missing values, including options to leave the latter be

This is solved by the possibility to attach another `Imputer` earlier in the pipeline, this handles only pre-existing missing values. The missing values caused by the reduction are handled by the `impute` setting, and the strategies for the two could in-principle be different.

issue.title: [BUG] Errors when using the recursive strategy in make_reduction when forecasting panel data

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
<!--
--> I experience errors when using panel data and the recursive strategy in make_reduction. I would like to use scikit-learn regressors to perform global forecasting on panel data but the predict method is giving me errors that I do not know how to solve.

Side note: in the reproducible code I set the multiindex to integer values because otherwise this also produces an error.

**To Reproduce**
<!--
Add a Minimal, Complete, and Verifiable example (for more details, see e.g. https://stackoverflow.com/help/mcve

If the code is too long, feel free to put it in a public gist and link it in the issue: https://gist.github.com
-->

```python
<
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
from sktime.utils._testing.hierarchical import _bottom_hier_datagen
from sktime.forecasting.compose import make_reduction
from sktime.forecasting.model_selection import temporal_train_test_split
from sktime.forecasting.base import ForecastingHorizon
from sklearn.linear_model import LinearRegression
from sktime.datatypes import check_raise

y = _bottom_hier_datagen(no_levels=1)
check_raise(y, mtype="pd-multiindex", scitype="Panel")

date_length = y.index.get_level_values(1).shape[0]
level_length = y.index.get_level_values(0).shape[0]
y = y.set_index(y.index.set_levels(np.arange(date_length), level=1))
y = y.set_index(y.index.set_levels(np.arange(level_length), level=0))

y_train, y_test = temporal_train_test_split(y, test_size=5)

forecaster = make_reduction(LinearRegression(), strategy='recursive')
horizon = pd.unique(y_test.index.get_level_values(1))
fh = ForecastingHorizon(horizon, is_relative=False)
forecaster.fit(y_train, fh=fh)
y_pred = forecaster.predict()
>
```

Error message preview:

TypeError                                 Traceback (most recent call last)
c:\Users\WREGTE16\Documents\GitHub\nl_sales_forecast\testing\a.ipynb Cell 1 in <cell line: 24>()
     [22](vscode-notebook-cell:/c%3A/Users/WREGTE16/Documents/GitHub/nl_sales_forecast/testing/a.ipynb#W0sZmlsZQ%3D%3D?line=21) fh = ForecastingHorizon(horizon, is_relative=False)
     [23](vscode-notebook-cell:/c%3A/Users/WREGTE16/Documents/GitHub/nl_sales_forecast/testing/a.ipynb#W0sZmlsZQ%3D%3D?line=22) forecaster.fit(y_train, fh=fh)
---> [24](vscode-notebook-cell:/c%3A/Users/WREGTE16/Documents/GitHub/nl_sales_forecast/testing/a.ipynb#W0sZmlsZQ%3D%3D?line=23) y_pred = forecaster.predict()

File c:\Users\WREGTE16\Miniconda3\envs\forecasting\lib\site-packages\sktime\forecasting\base\_base.py:331, in BaseForecaster.predict(self, fh, X)
    328     y_pred = self._vectorize("predict", X=X_inner, fh=fh)
    330 # convert to output mtype, identical with last y mtype seen
--> 331 y_out = convert_to(
    332     y_pred,
    333     self._y_mtype_last_seen,
    334     store=self._converter_store_y,
    335     store_behaviour="freeze",
    336 )
    338 return y_out

File c:\Users\WREGTE16\Miniconda3\envs\forecasting\lib\site-packages\sktime\datatypes\_convert.py:241, in convert_to(obj, to_type, as_scitype, store, store_behaviour)
    238     as_scitype = mtype_to_scitype(to_type)
    240 # now further narrow down as_scitype by inference from the obj
--> 241 from_type = infer_mtype(obj=obj, as_scitype=as_scitype)
    242 as_scitype = mtype_to_scitype(from_type)
    244 # if to_type is a list, we do the following:
    245 # if on the list, then don't do a conversion (convert to from_type)
...
df-list: obj must be list of pd.DataFrame, found <class 'pandas.core.series.Series'>
numpy3D: obj must be a numpy.ndarray, found <class 'pandas.core.series.Series'>
pd-multiindex: obj must be a pd.DataFrame, found <class 'pandas.core.series.Series'>
nested_univ: obj must be a pd.DataFrame, found <class 'pandas.core.series.Series'>

**Expected behavior**
<!--
-->

I would expect this code to perform a global forecast over all levels in the panel dataset, as the make_reduction strategy is set to 'recursive' which has 'pd-multiindex' as y_inner_mtype.

**Additional context**
<!--
-->

**Versions**
<details>

<!--
Please run the following code snippet and paste the output here:
 
from sktime import show_versions; show_versions()
-->
System:
    python: 3.8.13 (default, Mar 28 2022, 06:59:08) [MSC v.1916 64 bit (AMD64)]
executable: c:\Users\WREGTE16\Miniconda3\envs\forecasting\python.exe
   machine: Windows-10-10.0.19044-SP0

Python dependencies:

   setuptools: 61.2.0

issue.title: [ENH] global/local recursive reduction prototype

labels.name: implementing framework
labels.description: Implementing frameworks for new learning tasks

labels.name: interfacing algorithms
labels.description: Interfacing existing algorithms/estimators for other packages

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
Global/local recursive reduction prototype along the lines of https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/3327.

Dependent on https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/3327 as it uses a joint reduction mixin, refactored from https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/3327.

Addresses https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/3224 and #3316

body: Thank you for this refactor. ` RecursiveReductionForecaster`  doesn't work with keras models that are imported from `sktime-dl` unlike `make_reduction` scitype=time-series-regressor, right? It seems to just work with sklearn models

These changes are great. I was wondering: what about the use of covariates in X of which we do not know the future values? Sklearn regressors are capable of handling these, but might they need any special treatment in the reducer? For example, when we have a dataset of past data we do have the future (test) values for these covariates. But in order to test a realistic scenario, we would need to set our test set's future values for this covariate to NA (I assume). Could this perhaps be something handled by the reducer? Or maybe in the form of a transformer, that can be passed to the reducer?

Thank you for your proposition @fkiraly. Isn't it more general to use a dictionary to define the windows and functions to apply to `y` or to `X` as in `WindowSummarizer` ? This way we can define the columns to lags in X, when the lag starts, which aggregate window to apply; similarly for `y` without the choice of the column.
